awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Intensive Mentored Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) in Psychology and Neuroscience at an Urban Public College
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. It has both scientific and societal benefits, and integrates research and education. The Brooklyn College (BC) of the City University of New York REU program aims to advance discovery for the scientific and broader communities while promoting mentoring, learning, and professional development by: (1) immersing students from underrepresented groups (primarily women, racial minorities, first-generation college students) in innovative research in psychology and neuroscience; (2) guiding students through the scientific process, from generation of research questions to communication of results; (3) engaging students in didactics that highlight the relevance and applied value of their laboratory work; (4) enhancing students' competitiveness for graduate school and professional positions; and (5) boosting the research competence of local middle and high school teachers with downstream positive learning effects for their students. This REU program also enables faculty members to supervise talented individuals who might otherwise miss out on mentored laboratory and professional development opportunities, and contributes to the training and advancement of the next generation of scientists. 

The central (scientific) component of this REU program is a semester-long laboratory immersion, under the supervision of Psychology, Biology, and Chemistry Department faculty mentors, which results in a completed research project. We emphasize the generation of high quality research and integration of psychological and neuroscientific theory with the design, execution, and interpretation of data. We select ten students annually for mentored research projects, especially undergraduates from ethnic-minority serving, public two-year and four-year institutions in the New York metropolitan area. Students also attend weekly didactics: a seminar that dually focuses on psychology and neuroscience principles/research methods and professional issues/career development; a journal club that familiarizes students with scientific literature through learning to select, read, critically analyze, and present summaries of original research papers; and a statistical methods seminar that emphasizes data analysis, statistical reasoning, and presentation of research findings in academic contexts. Given the importance of adhering to ethical norms in research, our students also undergo an intensive scientific ethics training. As a capstone experience, students present a poster at the BC Science Research Day, where they compete for awards based on the quality of their work and ability to communicate their findings. Many of our students work with their mentors to publish their results in peer-reviewed journals. In addition, the project has a RET (Research Experiences for Teachers) component, which provides local middle and high school teachers with coursework in research methods, mentored laboratory experience, and professional development opportunities to enhance their research competencies and raise the level of science education in local middle schools and high schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
From 2018 to 2021, the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program at Brooklyn College (BC) immersed diverse students in innovative research in the fields of psychology, biology, and neuroscience and offered professional development opportunities to first-generation and minority students. We engaged students in the excitement of scientific discovery while providing critical preparation for graduate study and future professional endeavors. Thirty-one outstanding undergraduate students were enrolled including those from ethnic-minority serving, public, two- and four-year institutions in the NYC metropolitan area. Figure 1 presents demographic characteristics of BC REU students aggregated over the award period. In addition, the project had a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) component that provided six middle and high school teachers with coursework, mentored laboratory experience, and professional development opportunities to enhance their research competencies and raise the level of science education in local public schools.  

The central component of the BC REU program is a semester-long laboratory immersion, under the supervision of dedicated faculty mentors, culminating in a completed research project and presentation. We emphasize the generation of high-quality research and integration of psychological and neuroscientific theory with the design, execution, and interpretation of data. In 2019 and 2021, REU students presented first-authored posters at the BC Annual Science Research Day, where they competed for college-wide, interdepartmental awards based on research quality and their ability to clearly and effectively communicate findings (Figure 2). In 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic led to the cancellation of the BC Science Research Day; instead, REU students presented their research at local and national conferences that were held virtually (e.g., American Psychological Association annual conference). Figure 3 displays sample REU presentations from the award period and Figure 4 lists select publications and presentations. 

REU students also attended weekly seminars instructed by graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to complement their laboratory work and highlight its relevance and applied value. These didactics included: (1) a seminar that dually focused on psychology and neuroscience principles/research methods and professional issues/career development; (2) a journal club that familiarized students with scientific literature through learning to select, read, critically analyze, synthesize, and present summaries of original research papers; and (3) a statistical methods seminar that emphasized data analysis, statistical reasoning, and presentation of research findings in academic contexts. Given the importance of adhering to ethical norms in research, our students also underwent scientific ethics training.

An important goal of the REU program was to increase participation of students from underrepresented groups (e.g., women and non-binary genders, racial minorities, veterans, first-generation college students) in the fields of psychology and neuroscience, beyond the REU program. Of our 31 students, 7 have already enrolled in competitive doctoral programs, 1 has enrolled in medical school, 1 is undertaking a post baccalaureate program, 10 are enrolled in master's degree programs (in disciplines such as experimental psychology and neuroscience), 5 are research assistants or study coordinators, and the remainder are still completing their undergraduate studies or preparing for graduate school. 

For our RET program, we recruited six talented teachers from middle and high schools in NYC. To boost recruitment effects, we teamed up with the New York City Department of Education to advertise our RET program to public school teachers. We also transitioned our application process to an online platform to increase accessibility, and we developed an online evaluation survey that enabled us to understand our program's strengths and impact while identifying areas for improvement. Teachers highly rated their overall research experience and cited the mentored research as the aspect of the RET program that contributed most to their learning and growth. As a result of the experience, teachers made the most gains in: 1) recognizing sound arguments and appropriate use of evidence; 2) working effectively with others; 3) identifying patterns in data; and 4) finding and reading articles. The RET program continues to serve as a critical pathway toward student growth and engagement in psychology, biology, and other STEM fields. 

We are engaged in ongoing research related to REU and RET outcomes. In March 2022, PI Laura Rabin presented an overview of the program and select outcomes at the National Social Science and Technology Conference. As the theme of this conference focused on technology, Dr. Rabin highlighted changes made to our program to accommodate remote research and instructional activities. She also tracked REU students' attitudes, abilities, and competencies (in various areas of research), in relation to the impact of COVID-19 (Rabin et al., 2022).

Over the past three years, we overcame pandemic-related challenges to conducting innovative research and successfully trained 31 undergraduate students and 6 local teachers through our various laboratory immersion, didactic, and professional development opportunities. Today, we are closer than ever to our goal of helping close the gap of representation in STEM research by promoting the education and success of diverse individuals who will become the next generation of scientists. 


Last Modified: 05/20/2022
Modified by: Laura Rabin
